artist: Artist: Utagawa Kunisada; Publisher: Kitaya Magobei
creditline: Gift of Louis W. Hill, Jr.
markings: red artist\'s toshidama seal; censor seal: 村 {Mura}; publisher\'s seal:  喜多孫 {Kitamago}
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
portfolio: From Wrestling Match Between Sumo Puppets and Flowers (Sumō ningyō hana no torikumi 相撲人形花の取組)
signed: 應需國貞改二代豊國画 {ōju Kunisada aratame nidai Toyokuni ga}
text: This print belongs to a series of five showing beautiful women holding puppets that represent popular wrestlers of the day (it’s unclear if these puppets actually existed or were an invention of the artist). Hidenoyama Raigorō (1808–1862) was one of the greatest wrestlers in the Edo period. In 1847 he was appointed the ninth yokozuna in the history of sumo, the highest rank possible for a wrestler.
title: Puppet of the sumo wrestler Hidenoyama Raigorō
